answers.answer: Sorry for all of the typos

Hi frustratedlyconsfused and welcome to the forum.I'm sorry about all your suffering and you miscarriages.I cannot imagine how traumatic it must be for you and your family.Currently, I'm studying epigenetics and how to bypass genetic mutations, which is the new medical "frontier" , holding incredible promise in dealing with serious & complex (often unexplained) health conditions.I will post  soon again in regards to possible genetic mutations and your health concerns and history, as I have some matters to take care of at present.Please stay strong and remain hopeful as there are more things to explore  which may give some answers you are looking for.Take care,Niko

You are very welcome.I think there are too many events and unexplained symptoms in yourpost which point to what I suspect, however, I must make clear that it is the synergy of many factors that contribute to individual situations.Genetics, viral load, environmental factors, heavy metals, etc. are usually involved, which is useful to explore and correct,  where possible, when return to optimal health is desired.So, I'll  give you some information on MTHFR gene mutation, which I'll keep as simple as possible and without going into any complicated technical details.MTHFR (Methylenetetrahydofolate Reductase)  is a gene which signals an enzyme with the same name MTHFR.Mutations in this gene result in lowered activity of the enzyme, potentially causing serious health problems.One of its many functions is to convert folate to a methylated form of folate (5-Methyltetrahydrofolate). 5-Methyltetrahydrofolate is used to convert Homocysteine  to MethionineWhen the enzyme MTHFR is not activated or partially activated, homocysteine will not be properly converted to Methionine and will be elevated in serum. A consequence of this-->  histamine produced in your body does not get broken down.Elevated Homocysteine has also been associated with a higher incidence of various serious  diseases.Research shows that high homocysteine levels and/or those with the MTHFR mutation- even without elevated homocysteine, as its levels fluctuate- show a higher propensity for thrombosis (blood clots), arteriosclerosis , Alzheimer’s, stroke, heart attack, ***Fibromyalgia, ***migraines , osteoporotic fractures, bone marrow disorders and for those of child bearing years, it has found to be connected to higher incidences of down’s syndrome, spina bifida, other neural tube defects,  trisomy,***miscarriage, ***stillbirth, implantation failure, placental abruption, preeclampsia, higher incidences of autism, amongst others. :(If you were to test positive you may want to have your parents, siblings, and your children  tested, as well.Independent of MTHFR mutations (there are many) if hypothyroid with low thyroxine (T4) and low Riboflavin, your MTHFR enzyme activity will be impaired. You should have your thyroid function assessed by gettingtests for Free T3, Free T4 and Reverse T3.  Your t3/rt3 ratio is the best indicator for thyroid function which should be 20 methylocobalamin and 5-Methyltetrahydrofolate (methylfolate) respectively,are commonly caused by Gene mutations like the MTHFR , the most significant factor in methylation impairment  specifically the 677 and the 1248 mutations, which affect about 40-50% of the population, in various degrees.MTHFR Gene  testing. One of the least expensive places for this is23andMe, which will send you back "raw data" (no analysis) which needs interpretation.No problem. If you decide for that , let me know and I can give you a couple links where you can upload the data and get the answers for free .Or you can do your own research for that.Please let me know if you need additional details, however,please note thatmy comments and suggestions are not intended to replace medical advice.Best wishes.NikoPS Chronic inflammation without resolve due to increased production of B cells and decreased production of T cells, is another presentation of certain MTHFR mutations, due to undermethylation.

Correction--->...Independent of MTHFR mutations (there are many) if hypothyroid with low thyroxine (T4) and low Riboflavin, your MTHFR enzyme activity will be impaired. You should have your thyroid function assessed by gettingtests for Free T3, Free T4 and Reverse T3.  Your t3/rt3 ratio is the best indicator for thyroid function which should be 20<Elevated levels of B12 and/or folate, may also indicate undermethylation issues, which will cause B12 or folate to accumulate in the serum, by not converting into their active methylated forms  methylocobalamin and 5-Methyltetrahydrofolate (methylfolate) respectively, which are commonly caused by Gene mutations like the MTHFR , the most significant factor in methylation impairment  specifically the 677 and the 1248 MTHFR mutations, which affect about 40-50% of the population, in various degrees...I must have erased a part of the paragraph accidentally. My apologies.Niko
They've checked my thyroids several times and all of the test come back normal.
Thank you for the information. They've checked my thyroids several times and the test all came back normal.

You probably missed the part -->...You should have your thyroid function assessed by getting tests for Free T3, Free T4 and Reverse T3.Please confirm what tests you had. The standard practice is to test for serum levels of TSH and T4 -sometimes T3 is included- but these indicate only serum levels, not thyroid function.In low thyroid conditions, your thyroid gland may be producing adequate levels of thyroid hormones, however, just like in diabetes 2 where the pancreas produces enough insulin, but there's insulin resistance, the same situation may exist in hypothyroid conditions, where there's resistance to the thyroid hormones.In the end, I'm not suggesting you have thyroid resistance, but you definitely need to rule it out, since it would be THE reason, nothing your doctors attempt in regards to treatment-other than some symptom management- would work effectively. Healing at the cellular level is thyroid-dependent.Thyroid resistance is suspect, not only because of some of your symptoms, but because of all the unresolved biological and perhaps mental stress (mental stress is something unique to everyone, depending on how it is processed) which usually leads to adrenal fatigue.It is common in adrenal fatigue to develop thyroid resistance, as the adrenals force a hypothyroid state, for adrenal recovery.

You need to seriously look into Lyme Disease being a possibilityI had many of the same symptoms as you. I was bedridden for months. I went from doctor to doctor to doctor. It was truely a nightmare. I finally looked into it and found out I had chronic, untreated Lyme Disease. The docs tried telling me I had fibromyalgia, but I honestly thought that sounded like a "shot in the dark" diagnosis.Lyme disease is a serious problem today. its an absolute EPIDEMIC in this country. many people are suffering from your symptoms and are going undetected and untreatedif you need any help feel free to email me! god bless you!

Hey Jjewels, you made some good points .Lyme disease has hundreds of faces and it could mimick just about any condition.How did you get diagnosed? Any co-infections?Do/did you have an LLMD?Did you get your testing done at IGeneX?How is your treatment going, or did you get it resolved ?Cheers.Niko

question: I have several lupus symptoms including but not limited to;butterfly rash (confirmed by doctor), joint pain (especially my knees and hips), rheumatoid arthritis, sensitivity to sunlight, headaches, fatigue, hair loss, along with several other symptoms. I've been diagnosed with pleurisy, neuropathy, and migraines. Sometimes I'm so weak I can't get out the bed. My knees are now starting to lock up. I work 2 jobs and I have a family. I'm constantly sleepy and the list goes on. I've seen several doctors. I've had a positive ANA test but they say that doesn't mean anything . My blood work also shows high inflammation levels and my red and white blood cell count is always off. I've had several other test come back either positive or inconclusive. The doctors act as if nothing's wrong and that everything is in my head. My specialist see the clinical symptoms but she always looks at me with a puzzled look. She gave me hydroxychlor 200mg but says it's a trial and that I may possibly have SLE and said she'll see me back in 3 months. Up until my first pregnancy at the she of 21 I'd never had to visit a doctor outside of routine visits. After my 1st child I had several miscarriages, which they said could be a part of lupus. My second pregnancy was high risk but I was never told why. I had more miscarriages and then became pregnant with my 3rd child which was even harder than the 2nd. After I had my 3rd child my doctor basically made me get my tubes severed and said it was too dangerous for me to keep having children but still didn't give my a reason why. She just said If I became pregnant again she wouldn't be my caring physician. About a month after my 3rd child is when my symptons started. That was 7 years ago. They've became worse and worse now I have kidney pain to add to the list. What the hell is going on with me?? I'm beyond scared and the doctors test me as if I'm a mystery. They won't give me pain meds even though the rest clearly stated that I had to levels to prove the pain is there and they refuse to diagnose me. I'm so full of life but I can't live it because I'm so limited due to all of my problems. Is there anyone out there that can please help me??
title: What do I do??!!
